name: Grilled Lemongrass Chicken with Vietnamese Nuoc Cham
description: Lemongrass chicken is a popular menu item in Vietnamese restaurants, and it's super easy to make at home. You can grill or broil the chicken in the oven, and the sweet and sour nuoc cham dipping sauce couldn't be simpler. Serve with rice or noodles, or put it in a banh mi sandwich!

video.name: Grilled Lemongrass Chicken Recipe
video.description: Lemongrass chicken is a popular menu item in Vietnamese restaurants, and it's super easy to make at home. You can grill or broil the chicken in the oven, and the sweet and sour nuoc cham dipping sauce couldn't be simpler. Serve with rice or noodles, or put it in a banh mi sandwich!

recipeIngredient: 1 stalk lemongrass (bottom half only, finely chopped)
Jasmine rice or rice vermicelli (for serving)

recipeInstructions.text: Pound the garlic and black peppercorns in a mortar and pestle until fine.
recipeInstructions.name: Pound the garlic and black peppercorns in a mortar and pestle until fine.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the lemongrass and pound into a rough paste.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the lemongrass and pound into a rough paste.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the oil, fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar and water and stir until the sugar is dissolved. Pour the marinade onto the chicken and mix well. Let marinate overnight, or at least 2 hours; stirring halfway in between if you can to make sure marinade is well distributed.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the oil, fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar and water and stir until the sugar is dissolved. Pour the marinade onto the chicken and mix well. Let marinate overnight, or at least 2 hours; stirring halfway in between if you can to make sure marinade is well distributed.

itemListElement.text: Preheat the grill on high heat.
itemListElement.name: Preheat the grill on high heat.

itemListElement.text: Oil the grill grates well then place the chicken on the grill, presentation side down, and cook with the lid closed for 1-2 minutes or until the chicken has nice grill marks. Rotate the chicken 90 degrees to get the crosshatch grill marks, and let them grill for another 1-2 minutes. Tip: Skinless chicken can be sticky, so use a grill spatula to scrape the chicken off the grill rather than grabbing them with tongs which could tear the meat.

itemListElement.text: Set the oven rack to the top position, about 3-4 inches away from the element, and preheat the broiler on high for 5 minutes. Line a baking sheet with foil (not parchment!) and place the chicken on the baking sheet, pretty side up.
itemListElement.name: Set the oven rack to the top position, about 3-4 inches away from the element, and preheat the broiler on high for 5 minutes. Line a baking sheet with foil (not parchment!) and place the chicken on the baking sheet, pretty side up.

itemListElement.text: Broil the chicken for 7-10 minutes, or until you have nice browning with little charred bits on the chicken. By the time this happens the chicken should be fully cooked. Don't flip the chicken; if you try to broil both sides the chicken will not have enough time to develop any browning—it's better to get a good char on one side than none!

itemListElement.text: Pound together the garlic and chili into a rough paste. Add the sugar and grind in a circular motion to break up the chilies further.  Add all remaining ingredients and stir until the sugar is dissolved. This can be stored in the fridge for a few weeks.

review.reviewBody: I have always assumed that making sauce in a mortar was better but not better enough to not use the processor. So, today I did both to test that idea. Sadly, the processor’s work load just decreased. The mortar version was way better. Thanks for the really great recipe and for inspiring me to bust my long held assumption!
Love this recipe I end up with left over chicken which I made rice paper rolls with definitely a delicious winner

This is a fantastic recipe and I used it with pork, where I left it for 24 hours.  Can I use this to freeze the pork/chicken in the sauce, to defrost and cook at a later date?  Does the sauce freeze well on its own?  I am just thinking on how to speed up making a weekday supper.  Any ideas?  Asian cooking newbie:)

🤩 This recipe is a winner! It's going in my cook book because it's a keeper!

This recipe was amazing and very difficult to screw up. I marinated the chicken overnight and made the sauce the next day. I only used 1tbs of sugar in the sauce though and thought it was great. (You can always add more, but you can't take away). I think next time I'd make the sauce the night before too while I have everything out, as it keeps fine. We had it with rice and also in salad wraps. It was delicious both ways, my wife was practically drinking the sauce! I highly recommend and will be making this regularly.

Thanks!
